summary: A video presentation by Alan Duffy on the theme of scientific discovery, human curiosity, and the research on dark matter.

events_list.video_caption: The video opens with a black screen that transitions to a logo reading "The Royal Society of Victoria" with the tagline "Promoting science since 1854." The scene then shifts to a lecture hall where Associate Professor Alan Duffy, from the Centre for Astrophysics and Supercomputing, Swinburne University, is speaking. The text overlay provides his name, title, and the date of the event, Thursday 12 September 2019. The video then cuts to a close-up of a man in a suit and tie, standing in front of a bookshelf filled with books, suggesting an academic or scholarly setting. The man appears to be speaking, as indicated by his mouth movements and hand gestures. The video maintains a consistent focus on the man, with the background of bookshelves providing a scholarly atmosphere. The logo of "The Royal Society of Victoria" is visible in the bottom right corner throughout the video, reinforcing the academic context. The video concludes with the man continuing to speak, emphasizing the importance of the topic being discussed.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker talking about how humans are curious about the world around them, referring to "boundaries, those frontiers of knowledge," and then speaks of "discovery" and the "simple truth" that it is good to discover and to question. The speaker then goes on to say that they are working to map the universe, and then remarks that beyond the shoreline exists a new world. He then expresses the drive to explore. The audio clip ends with a brief snippet of music.

The backdrop features logos of Swinburne and The Royal Society of Victoria, indicating the event's sponsors. The audience, seated in rows, appears engaged, with some members taking notes or using electronic devices. The room is well-lit, with bookshelves and a banner for The Royal Society of Victoria visible in the background, adding to the scholarly atmosphere. The video maintains a consistent setting throughout, emphasizing the academic and professional nature of the event.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a man introducing a discussion about the scientific realization that the universe has a dark side, outweighing what we can see by five times. He expresses that answering fundamental questions about dark matter drives a strong desire to learn more. He describes it as curiosity-driven, nearly obsessive, and wonders how many more years it will take to discover dark matter. At the end of his speech, there is another word that is not easily understood.

events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker with an enthusiastic tone, explaining "when we look out on the scales between the stars" we see clouds of gas and dust. He continues, stating that zooming in reveals that stars and gas clouds are distributed in "discrete objects that we call galaxies." Describing a hypothetical observation, he suggests picking "your favorite blank patch of sky," and pointing the Hubble Space Telescope at it. The clip ends with a sound effect that evokes anticipation.

events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing the vastness of space, stating "behind your thumbnail lies 6,000 individual galaxies," and suggesting that "all of this is an accounting error." His tone is serious and somewhat dramatic. He continues, explaining the components of simulations, where "gas is the yellow" and "blue is the dark matter."

events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker explaining how dark matter clumps begin to collapse and drag gas into a "forming halo" and giant cloud. He indicates this is the "missing ingredient" in simulations, suggesting that dark matter accelerates galaxy formation. The speaker's tone is informative and slightly academic. Following the explanation, a brief, quiet musical interlude plays, featuring a serene, ambient style.

events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing simulations that allow for detailed prediction of dark matter distribution, emphasizing the clumping nature and concentrating accumulations. He then reflects on how people might have studied dark matter before simulations, describing it as immensely difficult to picture the phenomenon. He draws an analogy to observing trees moving in the air, which is otherwise invisible, allowing the imagination to grasp the concept of the wind.

events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single male speaker drawing an analogy, "the analogy is even more apt". He explains that, similarly to how people were certain about the existence of air despite not knowing its composition, scientists now know dark matter exists through its effects on visible matter, even without knowing its exact makeup. He speaks in a steady, informative tone. The clip concludes with an indistinct sound.

events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker explaining the concept of matter and antimatter. He describes how bringing them together leads to annihilation and energy release, specifically "gamma radiation," which he characterizes as "very, very energetic light." The speaker has an informative tone. There are no apparent background sounds or music in the provided audio clip.

events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a single male speaker discussing a theory about dark matter being its own anti-particle, the speaker has a moderately fast cadence and enthusiastic tone. He describes mapping simulated universes and identifying structures, gamma radiation, and the density of dark matter, expressing excitement about the findings with a slightly rising intonation. His tone abruptly shifts towards disappointment as he says, "no".

events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker stating that "at the center of the milky way is a black hole." He continues to describe that there are many dead remnant stars called "pulsars" which release a lot of gamma radiation. He finishes by saying that "we're kind of just seeing... pulsars." The speaking tone is informative and conversational.

events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip features a single male speaker discussing the challenges of simulating self-interacting dark matter and its impact on visible matter behavior in galaxies. The speaker notes that it's unclear if self-interacting dark matter is necessary, given the uncertainty surrounding star formation and their interaction with galaxies, suggesting that there might be enough flexibility to align simulations and observations. However, the speaker mentions that as understanding of the visible sector improves, the demand for more complex dark matter models increases. He expresses a preference for a self-interacting dark matter model for its potential to offer a more interesting and complex "behavior ecology" that is currently unobservable. He attributes this inability to the challenge of seeing dark matter.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a captivating image of a spiral galaxy set against a deep blue cosmic background, with the text "Direct Detection" prominently displayed at the top. The galaxy's bright core and swirling arms are vividly detailed, creating a sense of depth and wonder. The scene transitions to a star-filled expanse, maintaining the "Direct Detection" text, as the camera pans across the cosmos, highlighting the vastness and beauty of the universe. A bright yellow sun appears, with a small blue planet orbiting it, emphasizing the concept of direct detection in astronomy. The narrative continues with a view of the sun and its orbiting planets, reinforcing the theme of direct observation. The focus then shifts to a detailed image of Earth, showcasing its continents and oceans, with the "Direct Detection" text still visible. The video concludes with a man in a suit and tie standing in front of a backdrop featuring the Royal Society of Victoria's logo and the text "Promoting Science since 1854 and Polar Science since 1974." He gestures animatedly, engaging the audience with his presentation, which ties together the themes of direct detection and scientific exploration.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single male speaker with an informational and slightly academic tone, describing an animation involving a "slowly spiraling Milky Way" and the motion of the sun through dark matter. The speaker explains how the "wind of dark matter" impacts the Earth's movement. He mentions that this wind is faster for half the year and then slower, claiming that dark matter will have collided with atoms.  The audio ends with the speaker stating that, as a result, the atoms are knocked flying.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a presentation slide titled "A better detector" featuring an image of a dome-shaped detector with a ruler for scale, credited to the SABRE Collaboration. The slide also includes the text "Catching Ghosts" and the logo of The Royal Society of Victoria. The scene transitions to a man in a dark suit and pink shirt, standing in front of a backdrop with the Royal Society of Victoria's logo and the text "Promoting Science since 1854 and Polar Science since 1974." He is holding a remote control and appears to be giving a presentation. The video then returns to the presentation slide, now showing a detailed diagram of the detector's internal components, labeled "PMT," "Crystal," and "PMT," with a blue outline highlighting the internal structure. The slide maintains the same title, credit, and logo throughout. The presenter continues to speak, gesturing with his hands, while the background remains consistent with the Royal Society of Victoria's branding. The video concludes with the presenter still engaged in his presentation, emphasizing the importance of the detector's design and functionality.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features a single male speaker, explaining a scientific concept using a measured tone, beginning with, "we don't make... very good dark matter detections." He describes building a detector with a "sodium iodide crystal" that flashes light when dark matter collides, detected by sensitive cameras. He explains the expectation that the detector will glow "more often when we move with the direction of the sun," due to the "headwind effect". He concludes by stating, "that is the principle of sailing".

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man in a dark suit and light pink shirt speaking at a podium, with a backdrop that reads "Promoting Science since 1854 and Polar Science since 1974." He gestures with his hands as he speaks, emphasizing his points. The scene transitions to a large screen displaying a satellite image of a city with a highlighted area, credited to Google Maps and Swinburne University. The screen then shows a split view with the satellite image on the top left, a construction site on the bottom left, and a poster for the Stawell Underground Physics Laboratory (SUPL) on the right. The poster includes images of people in safety gear and text about the laboratory's role in Australia's world-leading dark matter detection and neutrino research. The video returns to the man at the podium, who continues to speak and gesture, with the backdrop and podium remaining consistent throughout. The atmosphere is professional and focused on scientific research and collaboration.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker introduces the question of where to build an experiment, noting that the detector is sensitive to anything that will collide with it, including radiation from space. He indicates that they went to Stawell, the gold mine, and are currently excavating the underground laboratory at 1024 m depth, with the detector being placed there next year. He identifies that the project is called Saber and that it will sit and wait for the collision of a ghost-like particle that will cause the crystal inside to glow. The speaker concludes by saying that if that doesn't sound like the coolest experiment, he has failed tonight.

events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker stating, "We have never known so little about our universe." He says that "science is not done" and highlights our lack of knowledge about dark matter and dark energy, as well as what happens on scales smaller than quarks. He mentions the recent detection of gravitational waves and the discovery of black holes and emphasizes that there is "so much we don't understand." He continues by expressing the excitement of science not being complete and suggests that aspiring scientists have vast possibilities to explore, including an "entire dark universe."
